title: How to Clean an Oven with Baking Soda

steps.title: Take out the oven racks.
steps.content: Take out the oven racks. You should also remove anything else that is inside the oven, such as pizza stones or oven thermometers. Check to make sure nothing is left inside of the oven before you begin cleaning. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Scrape out the loose build-up.
steps.content: Scrape out the loose build-up. You may have a lot of burnt food and build-up in your oven. Try to remove as much of the loose build-up as possible before applying the baking soda. Use a plastic or silicone spatula to scrape off the loose matter. You don’t have to remove it all—just remove what is already loose or nearly loose. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Create a paste with baking soda and water.
steps.content: Create a paste with baking soda and water. Mix ½ cup (170 g) of baking soda with 3 tablespoons (14.8 mL) of water in a small bowl. Stir the mixture until it forms a paste that can be easily spread. Adjust the amount of water used if 3 tablespoons does not create a spreadable paste. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Spread the paste inside of the oven.
steps.content: Spread the paste inside of the oven. You can spread the paste by hand if you’re wearing rubber gloves. If that doesn’t work for you, you can also spread the paste with a clean spatula. Coat the interior of the oven with the paste. Do not apply the paste to the heating elements. [4] X Research source It’s okay if the paste turns brown or is chunky in some areas of the oven.

steps.title: Leave the paste on overnight.
steps.content: Leave the paste on overnight. The paste works best if you allow it to sit overnight or for 12 hours. If you don’t have that much time, you can let the paste sit for 40 minutes. You may have to repeat the process for a deep clean if you let it sit for a short amount of time, however. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Wipe off the baking soda.
steps.content: Wipe off the baking soda. Use a damp cloth to wipe off the paste after you’ve let it sit. Use warm water to dampen the cloth. You may have to firmly scrub to get most of the paste off. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Scrape off the rest of the paste.
steps.content: Scrape off the rest of the paste. You may have trouble getting all of the paste off with a damp cloth. If that’s the case, use a spatula to get the rest of the paste off of the oven. There may be some leftover residue, but that’s okay because you will use vinegar to remove it. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Spray vinegar inside of the oven.
steps.content: Spray vinegar inside of the oven. Pour white vinegar into a spray bottle. Spray the vinegar over the areas where residue remains from the paste. The vinegar will cause the baking soda to foam up. [8] X Research source

steps.title: Wipe down the oven again.
steps.content: Wipe down the oven again. Use a damp cloth to wipe off the foamy areas of the oven. If residue remains, use more vinegar and then wipe again. Continue to wipe until your oven is clean. [9] X Research source

steps.title: Clean the oven racks.
steps.content: Clean the oven racks. Sprinkle baking soda over the oven racks. Then, pour or spray white vinegar onto the racks. The baking soda should begin to foam. When that happens, submerge the racks into a tub or hot water. Allow the racks to sit in the water overnight. [10] X Research source

steps.title: Replace the oven racks.
steps.content: Replace the oven racks. Once you are finished cleaning, put the oven racks back into the oven. You can also put back in whatever you’ve taken out of the oven. Your oven is now ready for use. [11] X Research source
